bestBHT.bht: The parents of the man born blind asserted with certainty that he was their son, who had been blind since birth, thereby undermining the Pharisees' disbelief about the healing. Through their failed attempt to question the authenticity of the miracle, the Pharisees only ended up providing additional evidence to support its truth. The parents, though silent in their gratitude and lacking in courage to openly testify about Christ, did not diminish their son's powerful testimony. Even those who denied his identity still acknowledged the striking resemblance between him and their son, thereby confirming the reality of the miraculous healing.

John Calvin: By their silence they show their ingratitude; for, having received so distinguished a gift of God, they ought to have burned with desire to celebrate his name.

But though they prudently avoid danger, and continue this middle path, of testifying indirectly about Christ by the mouth of their son, yet this does not prevent the Holy Spirit from condemning their cowardice by the mouth of the Evangelist, because they fail to discharge their own duty.
How much less excuse then will they have, who, by treacherous denial, utterly bury Christ, with his doctrine, with his miracles, with his power and grace!
Philip Schaff: We know that this is our son, and that he was born blind."
In seeking for that which might invalidate the ‘sign,’ the enemies of Jesus have but obtained new testimony to its reality.
Archibald T. Robertson: We know that this is our son, and that he was born blind... These two questions the parents answer clearly and thus cut the ground from under the disbelief of these Pharisees as to the fact of the cure."
So these Pharisees made a failure here.
John Gill: We know that this is our son; for though his receiving his sight made a considerable alteration in him, yet his features were the same...
...there might be some marks in his body, which they were acquainted with, by which they knew assuredly he was their son.
...even those who said it was not he, yet they owned he was like him.

bhtAttempts.bht: The parents of the man born blind responded confidently to the questions of the Pharisees, affirming that this was indeed their son and that he was born blind. In doing so, they effectively refuted the doubts of the Pharisees regarding the reality of the miracle. The enemies of Jesus, in their attempt to find fault and discredit the sign, were ironically presented with even more evidence of its authenticity. The silence of the parents, while displaying their ingratitude and fear, did not negate the powerful testimony of their son. Their reluctance to openly testify about Christ did not excuse their failure to fulfill their duty. Despite their cautious approach, the Holy Spirit, through the Evangelist, recognized and condemned their lack of courage. Yet, even those who denied the man's identity acknowledged the undeniable resemblance between him and their son, providing further confirmation of the miracle.

The parents of the man born blind confidently affirmed that he was their son and that he was born blind, effectively disproving the doubts of the Pharisees. In seeking to invalidate the miracle, the enemies of Jesus unintentionally provided more evidence of its truth. While the parents' silence showed ingratitude and fear, it did not diminish the powerful testimony of their son. Although they avoided openly testifying about Christ, their cowardice was condemned. Even those who denied the man's identity acknowledged his resemblance, confirming the miracle.

The parents of the man born blind confidently confirmed his identity as their son and his lifelong blindness, effectively refuting the disbelief of the Pharisees. The enemies of Jesus, in their attempt to discredit the miracle, unintentionally provided further testimony to its reality. Although the parents remained silent and failed to fully acknowledge Christ, their son's powerful testimony still stood. Even those who denied the man's identity acknowledged his resemblance, serving as evidence of the miracle.

The parents of the man born blind asserted with certainty that he was their son, who had been blind since birth, thereby undermining the Pharisees' disbelief about the healing. Through their failed attempt to question the authenticity of the miracle, the Pharisees only ended up providing additional evidence to support its truth. The parents, though silent in their gratitude and lacking in courage to openly testify about Christ, did not diminish their son's powerful testimony. Even those who denied his identity still acknowledged the striking resemblance between him and their son, thereby confirming the reality of the miraculous healing.

The parents confidently affirmed that the man was indeed their son, who had been blind from birth, refuting the Pharisees' doubts about the healing. Ironically, in their quest to discredit the miracle, the enemies of Jesus unintentionally provided further testimony to its reality. While the parents' silence reflected ingratitude and a lack of courage to openly testify about Christ, their son's powerful testimony remained unchanged. Even those who denied his identity acknowledged his resemblance, providing undeniable confirmation of the miraculous healing.
